reviewText:
Quick, dark comedy...if you're not interested based on those three words, you're not interested. If you are, this is your new favorite show.

House Of Lies is fast-paced, quick-witted comedy skewering politics, sex, race, business...all equally and without scruples.

Amazing cast, great acting, stylized editing...this show has it all. Do yourself a favor and jump in.

If you have a liking for brutally ruthless, highly intelligent, adult humor (including language and sex) in a high stakes, cut throat, big business environment, go no further. My wife and I are absolutely addicted.
My wife and I only caught the pilot to this hilarious black comedy series! We can't wait to see the whole season on DVD! Hopefuly we won't have to wait too long!

Is This Why 75% of a Recent Yale MBA Class Applied to McKinsey & Company?

Then there is the follow up work that keeps on paying like an insurance residual!  Welcome to the world of Management Consultants.

Marty (Don Cheadle), Jeannie (Kristen Bell) et al work for the #2 rated firm.  Every week the team led by Marty travel to a different city to convince a business that they are the solution to whatever ails them.  The goal is to sign the deal with a teaser/idea and then ink a long term contract for "after work".

What I really liked:

1.) Having seen management consultant firms in action, I always questioned the value of their ideas, when in most cases they had at best a basic understanding of what "my" business entailed?  I have had some fun in this respect in the past

2.) The MA rating allows for no punches to be pulled.  Constant sex, foul language and adult situations abound!

3.) Ever since Veronica Mars was prematurely cancelled, I had it on my short list to see Kristen Bell in another program where I could "see" Kristen Bell

4.) The first episode draws you in and is a particular favorite of mine as it culminates by outlining how a major lender can garner positive press by offering a modification program, which is essentially a "shell game"

Some of the story lines are uneven.  Marty has a pill popping ex-wife (that happens to work for the #1 consulting firm) and a son that may be sexually ambiguous.  Jeannie is engaged to a "Richie Rich", though is seemingly unsatisfied.  Oh, there is also a potential merger that Marty opposes.

All in, this is a very good show with an excellent cast.
Kristen Bell is just one of the boys, nothing phases her..
Great show!  Binged watched all 5 seasons in a week!  I always loved Kristen Bell... but the entire cast is great and have awesome chemistry!  Great type of humor too!!  Definitely rated R.
This show has cheap humor and is transphobic, homophobic, and racist. Not in a clever way, not in a calling out type of way... just really lazy and humorless.

Since this series had a 4-star overall rating, I jumped right into Season 1, Episode 1.  After about two minutes, I paused the streaming and went to the reviews.  In this instance 2057 positive reviews were wrong and 567 mostly one-star reviews were spot on.  The producers of this series were obviously targeting an audience too unsophisticated to realize they were being distracted by nudity, sex, and vulgarity from noticing how shallow and empty the actual story is.

Excellent acting, witty writing, and an exciting story line (at least through season 1). Highly recommended if you're looking for a new series. I'm pleased to see that there are several more seasons to view as I'm just discovering this.

I don't get it. Am I supposed to like these totally corupt charaters? Am I supposed to find corupt behavior funny. Is the point to expose the curruption of a company? I don't like the characters, and now I don't like the actors. This series is disgusting.

A great cast of actors doing a stellar job of playing characters who are the prime examples of wasted lives: wastes of air, space, resources- living parasitic and self-centered existences purely for their own material self-gratification and contributing absolutely nothing back into the world they live in. The dialogue is clever, albeit unnecessarily crass and often offensive. Cheadle and Bell are top-notch in their roles. The storylines show the writers' ability to exemplify the ugliness of capitalist exploitation to the nth degree. All in all, if your version of entertainment is watching a train wreck and laughing at the destruction, this might be your kind of show. But unless these are the kind of people that you happen to like, there is not a single character on this show worth rooting for.

this is a very well-written and thought provoking series.  It is really about our values as Americans, and the seductive nature of achievement, moving up the ladder while maintaining one's essential self.

Cheedle is brilliant.  The reliance on sex and deception which are the foundation of the characters and situations take themselves to improbable limits.  The probability of this is what leaves the series within the limits of popular TV culture.  A morality play without morals is great entertainment, but always ends up in the same place.  We finally see Cheedle grapple with this, but just a tinge in Season 2.

my wife was interested in seeing this show-i was ambivalent. the first couple of shows i thought i'd need to bail, primarily because of two of the main characters and their adolescent behavior with one another. we are now on season three and i am hooked. all the characters have more depth to them and the adolescent behavior i mentioned has toned down. the plot lines are interesting and the show has both comedy and drama elements, going into issues of gender identity, racism and sexism. it is a well put together show and, as i said in the intro, i'm glad my wife made me watch it.

The writing and production of this show are pretty good, but my main problem is that it's another show about crappy people. I get the premise is a bunch of people who lie or polish turds or any number of other distasteful things, but this show is a reflection on how we might accept this. My guess is that people who loved the behavior of Sons of Anarchy characters will also love these people. At least the evil lead in Dexter was of value to society in SOME way.
That said... the side plot of the son is humanizing. Unfortunately, his parents are both scumbags and he really deserves far better.
The "pause action while I explain something" is a nice feature too, that thankfully does slow down a bit later on.

Substantively, it's a pretty solid production. It's an HBO series and has what you expect out of an HBO series: that you shouldn't be appalled going in by the language and the subject matter; that it's paced pretty well; that it's (over)acted okay; that it's written kinda/sorta alright. I think it's the writing that puts me off; each of the three I watched is formulaic and the formula is to take the rep company, set it up with the problem for the show, confront it with an obstacle and overcome the obstacle with some outrageous-sounding, mildly-creative solution in the last five minutes. Meanwhile, the company strips down to what the producers believe to be the raw essence of modern interpersonal communication and relating to each other but, dudes, you lay it on so thick it loses its shock value.

I'd like to know what's wrong here? What it's not got that'd make it what I want it to be? I think it's lack of higher vision at the top and in the center. This is business, though, and it's none of my business how you guys decide to run your business, particularly if you're making money doing it.

An interesting show, probably closer to 3 1/2 than 4 stars.  I suspect that some will just hate it and others will think it's the best thing since sliced bread.  If you like off beat shows about the slimy business of marketing and don't mind a bit of crudity and language etc. then I would give it a try.  A bit like a darker version of Mad Men.  If Mad Men was a 50's era big budget war movie then House of Lies would be Apocalypse Now with a touch of M.A.S.H. (the film not the TV show).

House of Lies is smart, witty, fast-paced comedy about a team of high dollar managing consultants. The humor is strictly for mature audiences, and there is gratuitous nudity and profanity, so be warned. Don Cheadle is brilliant as the team leader, and the four main cast members work together seamlessly. Cheadle somehow manages to give depth to a character who is quite shallow. He makes us empathize with a greedy wheeler-dealer who seemingly has no moral compass.
